17821602.review:
The final chapter of the Nightmares from the Deep trilogy.  

Game: Museum Director Sarah Black and her daughter Cory are kidnapped by the infamous Davy Jones during a public and seeming well attended museum presentation about Davy Jones (compiled from all the information Sarah had gathered during her first two adventures).  (All I can say about that is getting donations and funding for the museum repairs and more exhibits should be easy after such a supernatural, flashy, and public kidnapping.)  I digress.  The ever resourceful mother-daughter team manage to break out of their jail cell and attempt to leave Davy Jones ship but are recaptured.  Davy Jones is going to kill Sarah but Cory makes a contract with Davy Jones to save her mother's life.  Davy Jones instead of outright killing Sarah forces her to walk the plank.  (Typical pirate)  The adventure begins here.  Find Cory and break her contract (and every other contract Davy Jones has ever made along the way, including Davy Jones' own contract.) Sub-storyline: Find out even more about Davy Jones and just how he became the infamous "devil" of the sea, and why.  And who that mysterious girl ghost is and her relationship with Davy Jones.  

First I would like to say this game is nearly perfect in my opinion.  Good storyline: pathos, adventure, mystery, tradegy, redemption.  A slew of side characters that are both helpful, and depending on their nature intimidating, scary, amusing, or sincere.  Nothing seems forced or padded, the story moves along by "area" with little back tracking, and the various and variety of puzzles are intrigated well within the story.  It is NEARLY PERFECT because IN A SINGLE PLAYTHROUGH on expert level/mode the player CAN GET ALL BUT ONE ACHIEVEMENT (play three games of Mahjong).  Had the Bonus chapter picked up the Mahjong achievement (and counted toward any other unfilled achievements) this game would have been perfect.  Not that I mind a second playthrough, but a second playthrough just to get achievements is tedious.

Puzzles:  The usual fare for this series, nothing too hard, challenging or head scratching, just enjoyable little romps of finding objects or the pieces of something.  Mahjong, the signature of this series, can be played as well. 

The Hidden/Secret Finds are seahorses, puzzle pieces, and amusing pirate cards all but one relating to the other pirates the player meets on the island.

In this game I really like how the achievements are done.  They are divided up into three areas on Davy Jones' ship, and as each achievement is fulfilled the blank picture is filled in giving that area of the ship a complete look by the end.  The achievement I liked the best which amused me and made me very happy was the animal interaction achievement.  I do not know how many times I have clicked on birds, fish, bats, insects, and rats/mice in other HO games just to see what happens, and now I get an achievement for it.  Tres chic. 

The artwork, music, and cutscenes are all well done and appropriate for the time and place heard or seen.  

All in all, I highly recommend this game.

Sound und Stimmen wie gewohnt sehr gut, leider nur in Englisch mit  Deutscher Sprachausgabe und diesesmal bei mir keine groben Übersetzungsfehler. Einige Fehler sind mir denoch aufgefallen, wie z.B. die Fehlerhafte Darstellung am Anfang wenn man die Ruder auf bestimmte weise benutzt, dass links das kaputte Ruder erscheint, obwohl man es noch im Inventar hat...

Gesamtbild ist leider nicht mehr so gut, das Grafikgerüst ist für mich unverändert, etwas mehr hätte ich mit da schon erwartet. Die Spieldauer ist mit 6 Stunden ganz okay, für den Preis! Es gibt auch wieder Errungenschaften, die jedoch auch alle schon bekannt sind.

"Nightmares from the Deep 3: Davy Jones" is probably the best Artifex Mundi game I've played.  It's definitely the best of the "Nightmares from the Deep" series, and that series is one of their best.  Just about everything in this casual adventure Hidden Object Game (HOG) is better than it is in earlier works:  graphics, voice acting, and story.  Best of all, we aren't forced into a second full playthrough to get 100% Achievements.  A single playthrough on Expert plus doing the first three HOGs as Majhong in a second partial playthrough can get us everything.  Yay!  My only complaints (and they're very minor) are that I hate the daughter (which has been true in all three games of the series) and they have too many Fractured Object Games (FROGs).  I defnitely prefer HOGs to FROGs.

It took me 7.3 hours to get through the main story and an additional 1.9 hours for the Bonus chapter.  So, 9.2 hours of very good gameplay makes the game worth buying even at it's list price.  Of course, I bought it on sale :) .

You would think that after two romps, the daughter of this series would learn how to not be stupid.  Sadly, nope.  The mother is too busy unleashing horrible piratey ghosts to be a decent enough parent to tell her daughter to you know, stay out of it.  But here's counting on her for being stupid yet again in the fourth game.

16955754.review:
[h1]Short version: 86%[/h1]
There is no contest that despite the reused plot, Davy Jones is the best one of the series with its excellent hidden object scenes and puzzles, interesting story progression, and quality voice acting.

[h1]Long version:[/h1]
After the shallow beauty of the Siren’s Call, the Nightmares from the Deep series returned to its roots in this final chapter. So much so that the story is almost the same as in the ‘Cursed Heart’: the protagonist’s daughter gets kidnapped by a pirate’s ghost, and she has to follow them to a mystical island to learn the secret behind the pirate’s tragic past.
Despite this… reuse, the story does a much better job with great characters and good dialogues, making it one of the best titles in the Artifex Mundi stable.

The game offers good variety by using all three common hidden object scene types: item list, fragmented object, and sequential. The balance isn’t perfect though, as most of the difficulty is shifted towards these scenes and left the usual Artifex Mundi type puzzles quite easy.

Not that it makes any difference, as Davy Jones is an excellent closure to the trilogy and a great hidden object game overall.

16414690.review:
Davy Jones is the third installment of Nightmares from the Deep series by Artifex Mundi. Previous installments as follows: The Cursed Heart and The Siren’s Call.


[h1]Review[/h1]

Game Menu Option: Two section – Volume and Miscellaneous settings. The volume section has the following: Music and Sound. The miscellaneous section has the following: Custom Cursor, Voice Overs and Full Screen. Wide Screen is automatically supported in the game.

Game Difficulty Modes: Three game difficulty modes – Casual, Advanced and Expert.

Cinematic/Dialogues: All cinematic scenes can be skipped if you do not want to watch them. They can be watch over again under the video section the extras. There is an option for skipping the entire dialogue scene without having sit through it.

Game Music/Sounds/Voiceovers: The music definitely sets the mood for the game. The sounds aren’t intrusive as the game progresses. The voice overs in the game are nicely done.

Game Graphics: Nothing much can be said about the graphics asides from that they are nicely drawn with a painted feel to them.

Inventory Panel: There is an option to lock the inventory panel in place.

Notebook: Two section – Notes and Objectives. Notes section is for the story and clues from the game. Objectives section is for all the objective from the game and the completed ones are checked off.

Map: The map is interactive. The ability to fast travel to different locations in the game. Useful map indicator icons, the legend on the map explains the function for each of the map icons.

Hidden Object Gameplay: Fragment Items, Shadow Items, Traditional word list with some and/or no interaction required. For the traditional word only, the sonar feature show you the shape of the item. Most of the hidden object scenes can be replayed in the extra section.

Mahjong Gameplay: This game feature is optional for those who don’t want to go looking for items in hidden object scenes.

Puzzle Gameplay: Most of the puzzles are fairly easy to solve. There is a skip button if the puzzle(s) becomes too tasking to solve.

Game Ending: There is somewhat an ending in the main portion of the game but the bonus chapter extends it a bit more.

Game Bonus Chapter: Can be access after the main portion of the game is completed.

Game Achievements: Both in-game and Steam achievements. There 32 different achievements to earn in the game but they also comes with certain requirement into order to unlock them.

Game Collectables: Three different sets of collectables in the game. 10 Pirate Cards, 12 Seahorses, 1 Puzzle (24 Pieces.) They are scattered throughout the entire game.

Game Concept Art/Wallpapers: 12 concept art and 3 wallpapers.

Game Soundtracks: 6 soundtracks from the game.

Game Trading Card/Badge: This a special feature only available in the Steam’s version of the game. The game drops three different trading cards only once and the rest of the cards: Community Market, Booster Packs and Trading. The game badge can be crafted after having all the card in the inventory then it can be upgraded four more times.

15461769.review:
这游戏上个月刚发行这个月就进包，速度有点快啊。

从名字就能看出来，本作是 Artifex Mundi 社深海之心系列的第三部，也是最后一部。这家的游戏在Hidden Object界算是顶级的，一贯良心，各种中文+福利，本作也不例外；而且由于是最新一作+系列大结局的原因，本作在游戏性上也有了大幅度的创新，质量的提升和游戏体积的增加一样明显。

和前两部不同，这一部里女主大妈终于和前两部的幕后黑手Davy Jones 正面硬刚了，可喜可贺可喜可贺。和前两部剧情里收集若干个XX放到盒子上看黑历史不同，本作的剧情收集看黑历史是主线的一环，这种强制收集的设定也让玩家避免了最后各种跑路的麻烦。本作的流程比前两部短一点，剧情和一代诅咒之心有点相似，最终boss也果然洗的闪闪发亮（反正2代DLC就开始洗，毫无意外）；女主的女儿虽然依然是个拖油瓶不过没一代那么废柴了也算是一个进步。不过话说[spoiler] 一个是为了女儿做这做那的好爸爸，另一个是为了女儿出生入死的好妈妈，你俩战了三部不产生点感情么！	[/spoiler]

解谜方面，本作的解谜模式和第二部塞壬的召唤相似，也是多种寻物+小游戏的解谜方式。本作的解谜数量有所减少，玩起来比较顺，不会有前几作寻物过于密集的问题；但是难度也有所增加，和前两作寻物的多次寻物直到一图找到空不同，本作大多数图都是1个拼碎片+1-2个寻物，因此解谜时间和前两作持平。而且本作的小游戏难度上升了很多，有几个甚至让我觉得“休闲向整这么难大丈夫？”的级别，因此完美的难度也大大上升（本人一周目专家全成就大约4-6h，算是这公司游戏里时间最长的……）。不过之前贴心的跳过和麻将模式依然存在，成就也好刷很多，一周目无提示全寻物+二周目3个麻将就可以，方便了各位完美主义者。

其它部分……本作的3D建模技术明显提高，女主的女儿终于不再是个小胖妹，新出的萝莉也蛮可爱的；音乐还是系列老旋律，听了三代还是蛮亲切的；DLC算是后续，也没挖什么新坑，这系列应该算完结了……总的来说是个7.5/10分的优秀休闲作品，还有中文，推荐打折or进包的时候入一个玩玩看。

P.S.本作的翻译有些小问题（都是老问题了）：游戏里的“黑桃”=“Spade”=铲子，“光束”=“Beam”=横梁，一个和4相关的东西是用粉笔在写着2的板子上画加号。

15078327.review:
Artifex Mundi continues to impress with Nightmares from the Deep 3: Davy Jones, one of their best hidden-object adventure games to date. More so than their previous efforts, Davy Jones has an intriguing sense of personality and strong cinematic style that make it feel more like a big-budget title than an indie game. Artifex Mundi's detailed artwork has also gone from modestly attractive to drop-dead gorgeous; I think Davy Jones is one of the best looking games I've seen from the past couple of years.  

On the negative side, I still find the relatively linear, inflexible puzzle design to be irksome. There could be a lot more replay value if the game were designed with multiple puzzle solutions and different paths to take. More length would have also been nice, to make the game feel more epic and give the writers the opportunity to tell a more complex story. Still, the 5-6 hour, $10 game standard has its own appeal, and could be part of the reason why Artifex Mundi has been so successful. 

It may be the third game in its series, but Davy Jones stands alone, and is one of the best places to start if you're curious to experience a hidden-object adventure game for the first time. I'm already looking forward to the next time I dive in and rediscover all of Davy Jones' secrets.

(Rating: 7.5/10 “Good”)

14606781.review:
I had a coupon for this so figured I'd give it a go even though I'm not too keen on hidden object games... and I never played any of the other games in the series (turns out that doesnt matter, they are unrelated series). I was pleasently surprised by the game, and played the entire main game and then the bonus one in a little over 7 hours...straight. It is quite addictive, and this game gives the hidden objects genre a breath of fresh air. It's rich in plot, mystery, and intrigue. 

Okay, honestly at first... the narration... I was pretty convinced I had just bought a game for 7 year olds. I turned my volume down and continued onward. It tells you in the beginning to turn the sound up for a better gameplay experience and maybe it's just me, but I felt better just reading the captions.

I played it through the entire time on the middle (advanced/intermediate?) setting, but there is the option for expert which offers it's own acheivement and does make the game harder with click penalities and turning off visual clues, etc. There is also a easy mode if you have kids or you are really really lazy. 

There's  the obligatory stereotypical find the hidden objects, but multiple types: the empty silhouette (figure out what object you must find from the shape), the list of words and then there is the interactive which is quite neat ( Here's a non-spoiler fake example:  say you need a hot cup of water, you would need to find a cup, a heat source, and water and combine them to acheive the result.) These puzzles also help you by giving you a useful item you may need on your quest. Also, strange but nice, is the option to play a round of mahjong instead of the hidden object search. (I think there's also an achievement for playing 3 rounds of mahjong.) It may sound weird, but it comes in handy when your raging for the last thing on your list and don't want to use a hint or skip the puzzle (which are also achievements).

There are also tons of puzzles that involve logic skills and can take some time. Also, I found it quite interesting that you can travel between parts of the map freely once youve discovered them, and often need to go back and forth to complete objectives. That aspect really sets it apart and truly makes more of a point and click adventure first, hidden puzzle game second. 

Bottom line: worth 10 bucks? Probably not. Grab it with a coupon or when it's on sale, it's a great time killer and was unexpectedly fun. I'll buy more from the series when they're cheaper. It's 7 hours of my life I won't get back, but sometimes that's better than just watching TV, and it's totally worth a thumbs up.

14603263.review:
I havent played the previous two games in this particular series, so I was going in blind a bit here.
Turns out playing the previous games was absolutely not a prerequisite as this game worked fine as a stand alone.

Anyway, the game itself was fun. I didnt think the puzzles were too challenging. The only real challenge came from some of the hidden objects being somewhat indistinct and/or blending into the background, but I think that is te whole point of them being hidden, lol.

The graphics were really nice. As far as PnC games go, I'd say it had some of the better graphics I've seen, including some very good animations (such as the dog, the ghost, and so on). It was a very beautiful game.

The story was pretty decent. I dont think it will win any awards for writing, but I do think that it was, as I said before, pretty decent. With so many variations on the DavyJones lore that exists in the real world, film, writing, and so on, it gave the writers some leeway to be creative, and they did well with it IMO.

The voice acting...well...that wasnt so great IMO. Especially the daughter, who was just terrible. Some of the character voices were fun, but overall, I think this was the weakest aspect of the game.
 Which leads me to another aspect of the game: character interaction. For the most part, I think the writing and voice acting worked fine with the character interactions, but I also think there could be no more pathatic a character than the daughter Black, and the mom Black wasnt all that great in her interactions either. The pirates and the Witch on the other hand worked quite well, as did O'Malley. However, I think the dog stole the show, lol.

All in all, I had a good time with this game. The puzzles lent themselves to a casual experience, which I apreciated, the story was pretty decent, and the graphics were quite nice.

7.5/10

You know how you have something you enjoy doing that you feel maybe isn't the thing you should really be doing?  Like maybe you like eating at McDonalds, or jacking it to videos of Swedish weightlifters.  That's the way I feel about Artifex Mundi games.  I have them all, I've finished them all, but as much as I like them, I feel like I should be playing somehting more substantial.  Somehow I just like the calmness of it all.  The bland, monotone female protagonist, the puzzles that pretty much repeat from game to game, it's a simple, familiar formula, and it's comfortable.

     I can't really complain, I've gotten many hours of gameplay out of these point and click games featureing the same woman who for whatever reason cannot stop losing her daughter to various demons and ghosts that seem intent on kidnapping her.  Personally, if I was this ladies daughter, every time she wanted to go on a trip, I'd be like "Um, no thanks, but I've been kidnapped by demon ghosts the last five trips, I think I'll sit this one out."

     Overall, I really have a good time, or at least a relaxing time, playing these games, as the puzzles are not really challenging, and the scenes are well done.  If you are looking for a game that won't stress you out, or are someone who values bland voice acting, I would suggest that you try pretty much any Artifex Mundi game.

14355998.review:
The final entry in Artifex Mundi's popular hidden objects series Nightmares from the Deep and it is a worthy conclusion to the trilogy.
Once again you play as museum custodian Sara Black who along with her daughter get kidnapped yet again, but this time by the sea devil Davy Jones himself.
In a desperate attempt to save her mother, Sara's daughter signs a deal with Davy to let her go, but he instead leaves her to die at sea.
Now Sara must try and find a way to save her daughter from being held as a slave forever by Davy Jones AND also figure out a way to help all the other restless souls on the island.
As per usual, the artwork here is really well done and the voice acting ain't bad either, especially some of the skeleton pirates.
The mahjong minigame is also back incase you don't like looking through a clutter of items in a place for something important, although it is good practice for your eyesight to try finding the objects hidden there.
Plus this is the Collector's Edition too, so you get a second adventure when you complete the game for the first time.

14321418.review:
Fun casual logic game adventure; fun even if you don't know the other two games in the series.

Yes, it's a bunch of diffculty logic games strung together by a storyline with women protagonists (I wonder if that says more about Artifex Mundi or about its audience); no, I don't call it a "hidden object game" because you can now play Mahjongg instead of doing the hidden object puzzles; yes, it's casual, meaning you don't have to remember or read much, and the puzzles are of intermediate difficulty. The story is decent, but fairly forgettable; the skeletons are actually the most interesting characters in it.

This game has 8 different voice actors to bring across its storyline; I especially enjoyed the skeletons. There's an enormous amount of animation, mostly for cutscenes. The game is made for 4:3 screens and does run on older computers, but all of the pictures have painted margins so that the scenes fill a 16:9 screen as well.

Give the scope of the game (casual puzzle adventure), you will get about 6 hours of gameplay that are well crafted; I got a free copy via the "Davy Jones Welcome Giveaway", but it is certainly adequately priced, even if you missed the -40% release promotion (still ongoing as I write this).

Je tu závěr trilogie a už od prvních minut je tak epický, že tomu ani nebudete věřit. Celý jakoby prolog je tak strhující, že jsem nedokázal odtrhnout zrak od monitoru a s otevřenými ústy zíral na tu nádheru. Zatímco v prvním dílu jste se snažili zachránit svou dceru a ve druhém jste pomohli jedné mořské panně, zde nepůjde o nic menšího než o zastavení samotného Davyho Jonese. O ději bych toho nechtěl moc prozradit, protože je neskutečně vtahující (jak je dobrým zvykem u her od Artifex Mundi) a i když se tempo ke konci znatelně zpomalí, stále je tahle hra jejich nejlepším dílem. Protože všechno tu je na stejné úrovni - příběh, grafická stylizace (podobná minulým dvěma epizodám a přesto hezčí), hudba, dabing, neuvěřitelně zajímavé hádanky a tak akorát HOG her. + rozumné achievementy
+ délka hry kolem pěti hodin (na nejtěžší obtížnost a s hledáním všech věcí; možná to někomu přijde málo, ale pro mě to bylo tak akorát, navíc tu je i kratší doplňkové dobrodružství)
+ opravdu velice, ale VELICE zajímavé doplňkové dobrodružství, které se odemkne po dokončení hry (většinou je nudné a nezajímavé, ale tady chytne už od prvního okamžiku!)

- pro někoho možná až příliš věcí na sbírání (myšleno u achievementů)

Hodnocení: 10/10

Ano, odpustil jsem této hře ty dvě malé chybičky a dávám plné hodnocení. A proč? Protože přesně takhle má vypadat zakončení trilogie. Hra vás už od intra chytne a nepustí, dokud neuvidíte závěrečné titulky. Tohle je pro mě nový král jak her do Artifex Mundi, tak i HOG žánru celkově. Nejde nic jiného, než ji doporučit.

14287471.review: Third in the Nightmares from the Deep series of HOG's from Artifex Mundi, NFTD: Davy Jones continues with the same protagonists from the first two games (same voice actor as in many AM games) to tell a new twist on the Davy Jones folklore.  Standard features from AM games are present, HOG puzzles with a Mah Jongg tile-matching alternative, as well as all the other variants of puzzles that have made an appearance in other AM games.  However, nothing new in terms of puzzle mechanics really.  Nice graphics as usual, decent voice acting, and a nice story.  There's also an "extra" side story after the completion of the main story as usual, for a total of about 5 hours of gameplay.  However, don't expect character continuity based on the situation.  Example, if you get to the end of the game and you want to check prior scenes for collectibles, you'll see the characters in multiple places.  Essentially they aren't movable, they're set pieces.  Get the game on sale as usual, very little replayability save for collectibility.

14268904.review:
Nightmares from the Deep Davy Jones ist der Dritte Teil dieser Wimmelbild-Reihe von Artifex Mundi.
Wie auch in dne beiden Vorgängern, geht es um piraten, den Fluch des Untodes und das Geheimniss des berüchtigsten aller Piraten: Davy Jones höchstpersönlich!
In rund 6 Stunden (mit Bonusabenteuer) erleben wir eine sehr spannende Geschichte, die man auch erleben kann, ohne die Vorgänger zu kennen, die Story ist nämlich nicht verwirrend oder undurchsichtig.
Die Musik wurde aus Teil 1 und 2 übernommen, es gab keine Neue, gestört hat mich das persönlich nicht. Es hat eben den selben Charme wie seine Vorgänger. Die Musik wurde passend zu der aktuellen Szene gewählt.
Übersetzungsfehler in den Wimmelbilder waren nicht vorhanden, die Minispiele wieder typisch für AM, dennoch machte es Spaß und war hier und da auch eine kleine Herausforderung.

Beim ersten Durchgang dürfte man 31 / 30 Erfolgen schaffen, für den mahjong-Erfolg muss man eben einen zweiten Spielstand bis zum dritten Wimmelbild spielen. Die zu suchenden Objekte - Seepferd, Karten und Puzzleteile - sind gut versteckt, manche Bilder musste ich mehrmals gründlichst durchsuchen, um sie zu sehen. Aber es ist kein Ding der Unmöglichkeit.
Kniffliger fand ich hingegen den Erfolg, dass man mit allen 16 Tieren innerhalb der Insel interagieren muss. Ich war mir sicher jedes gesehene Tier angelickt und auch einige durch Beeren aus ihrem Versteck herausgelockt zu haben, dennoch fehlt mir dieser Erfolg.

Wer Nightmares from the deep "The Cursed Hearth" und "The Sirens Call" gespielt hat, sollte auch bei "Davy Jones" nicht nein sagen, sondern zuschlagen. "Davy Jones" finde ich besser gelungen als Teil 1 und in etwa gleichwertig mit Teil 2, der mir besser gefiel als der Erste. Auch ein Vollpreiskauf lohnt sich.

14267397.review: The great and interesting game!! Thanks a lot!

14263432.review: So if you're looking to buy this game, there's a good chance you've played the first two... or you're a pirate fan. Either way, you won't be disappointed. Artifex Mundi gives us some of the best Hidden Object games and now we can add Nightmares from the Deep: Davy Jones to that list. Fun story, nice graphics, bonus things to look for (Glowing Seahorses, Pirate Cards, etc.), puzzles are perfect (not too easy and not too hard), very enjoyable HO scenes, and a few things that'll make you laugh. Music is the same as the first two games, piratey and hauntingly beautiful. Add in cards and achievements and you've got everything you could want! The story continues the plot of the first two Nightmares from the Deep so, if you enjoyed those games, this is a must buy. Even if you haven't played those, if you're an HO fan, this is sure to please.  :)

Аляповатая смесь «Пиратов карибского моря», «Индианы Джонса» и «игры в бирюльки», полная логических артефактов, зато про пиратов! Guilty pleasure III.

[h1]Сравнение с предыдущими сериями[/h1]
По сравнению с [url=http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198084019881/recommended/259740/]Nightmares from the Deep: The Cursed Heart[/url] и даже с [url=http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198084019881/recommended/284790/]Nightmares from the Deep 2: The Siren`s Call[/url] поляки из Artifex Mundi предложили вполне сказочную анимацию и что-то уже похожее на вменяемый сюжет с внезапными поворотами, но, о ужас, опять ввели в игру отмороженную дочь главной героини. NPC традиционно спихивают на директрису исторического музея решение накопившегося за века (sic!) вороха проблем, а сами терпеливо ждут, пока она чертыхаясь ищет иголку в куче мусора (ещё раз sic!), ну или раскладывает маджонг. Лава течёт — а кровь из носа приходится собирать арбалетную стрелу из палки, камня, перьев и верёвки! Но, кроме шуток, тут добавили саспенса  и даже целую [i]одну[/i] сцену с возможностью выбора вариантов ответа. Так что могут, когда хотят. А так это те же рельсы, только ещё более красиво раскрашенные.

[h1]Локализация[/h1]
Выбор языка (субтитры и интерфейс) в самой игре отсутствует, поэтому это следует сделать заранее в клиенте Steam: Правая кнопка мыши на названии игры→ Properties → вкладка LANGUAGE.

Обратил внимание, что названия предметов для поиска не всегда переведены адекватно, то есть встречаются слова вида «ладонь» вместо «скипетр», или «затычка» вместо «кран», что не особо принципиально при казуальном прохождении, так как всегда есть возможность попросить помощь, но если хочется в «поиске предметов» обойтись без случайных кликов и подсказок, то от русского языка следует отказаться.

[h1]GNU/Linux[/h1]
Ubuntu 16.04, ноутбук cо встроенной графической картой Intel® HD Graphics 4400. Имеется распространённая проблема с зависанием игры при переходе из полноэкранного режима по ALT+Tab или при всплывании внешних окон, включая сообщения о появившихся карточках. Если подавить всплывающие окна, то больше сложностей не возникает.

[h1]Обзор входит в список [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1103944566]Игры, Linux, Steam, обзоры[/url].[/h1]
